instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V looping on one port
threads.message:
Hi Folks, 

Have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which is looping on one port 0 - 5V closest to the screen, while the other one is stable 5V closest to the trackpad.

Would you say this is a faulty USB-c controller? The one looping is the closest one to the screen which I believe is controlled by <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

All other voltages are looping including <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> when connected on that port.

When power supplied to the closest to the trackpad port, some of the measurements are:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>TBA_HPWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 5V

Thanks

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V looping on one port
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings on all LDO outputs of both chips.
The other chip should be the culprit...

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V looping on one port
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> is shorting to the ground.
Does it worth checking possible shorting caps or shall I hit the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>?

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V looping on one port
threads.message: You can remove <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> first, but very likely bad <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

threads.title: SOLVED <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V looping on one port
threads.message: Thanks [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER], the cap was okay. As suggested <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> was the culprit.
